Legal_Issue: Whether the plaintiff qualifies for manufacturing and processing tax deductions, investment tax credits, and accelerated capital cost allowance
Legal_Provision: Sections 125.1, 127, and Schedule B of the Income Tax Act
Legal_Framework: Income Tax Act provisions on deductions, credits, and allowances for manufacturing/processing businesses
Grounds_for_Claim: Plaintiff's business activities constitute manufacturing and processing under the Act
Applicant_Challenge: Classification of business activities by the Minister
Procedure: Trial with evidence on business operations, followed by appeals based on interpretation of the Income Tax Act
Outcome_of_Review: Plaintiff's income qualifies for manufacturing/processing deductions
Decision_Outcome: Plaintiff entitled to claimed tax benefits
Remedy_Requested: Tax deductions, investment tax credits, accelerated capital cost allowance
Remedy_Sought: Recognition of manufacturing/processing status under the Income Tax Act
Evidence_Assessment: Activities involve mixing, blending, and pressurizing goods at well sites
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of business operations involving preparation and sale of special mixtures
Evidence_Type: Operational and procedural evidence of business activities
Burden_of_Proof: On the plaintiff to demonstrate qualification as a manufacturing/processing business
Credibility_Factor: Consistency of operational practices with manufacturing/processing definitions
Defendant_Response: Minister disputed classification of activities as manufacturing/processing
Legal_Rule: Businesses engaged in manufacturing/processing qualify for specific tax benefits under the Income Tax Act
Legal_Rule_Source: Sections 125.1, 127, Schedule B, Income Tax Act
Authority: Canadian tax court and appellate authorities
Jurisdiction: Federal tax jurisdiction under the Income Tax Act
Pending_Relief_or_Application: Granting of tax deductions and credits
Procedural_Issue: Interpretation and application of tax law provisions
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Fair hearing provided during trial and appeal
